body:
I'm able to reproduce this bug with this code;
```python
def my_fxn(id):
    """
    my_fxn does something important.

    id	             string [Optional]	id for ecommerce
    """
    return None
```

I'm also running black version; `20.8b1` and python `3.9.0` on OSX `Darwin Kernel Version 19.6.0`

Running `black` on a load of legacy code, I hit this too so I dug into it and have figured out what is wrong and produced a workaround. However, given that I am unfamiliar with `black`, I don't know whether the workaround is OK (if a unit-test were added) or not.

This minimal example that I was able to produce was:
```python
print "Something"

def bar():
    """Testing
    Testing """
    pass
```

The issue seems to be that, when parsing Python 2 (caused, I think, by the use of the `print` statement), the docstring node value ends up being a `bytes` rather than a `str` -- which results in the string normalization not being performed. As the docstring in the example has a trailing space that `black` removes, the equivalence check fails as a result.

Changing the normalization to operate on `bytes` as well as `str`s works around the problem:

```python
            # Constant strings may be indented across newlines, if they are
            # docstrings; fold spaces after newlines when comparing. Similarly,
            # trailing and leading space may be removed.
            if (
                isinstance(node, ast.Constant)
                and field == "value"
                and isinstance(value, (str, bytes))
            ):
                regex = r" *\n[ \t]*"
                replacement = "\n"

                if isinstance(value, bytes):
                    regex = regex.encode()
                    replacement = replacement.encode()

                normalized = re.sub(regex, replacement, value).strip()
            else:
```
However, I'm not convinced that this is the best option - ideally the value should be a `str` for both Python 2 and Python 3 parsing...
I'll let someone who knows `black` better decide the best way forward - though I'm happy to convert this into a PR, if it should be the right thing to do...

By the way, I wonder if this would now be clearer:

```python
            # Constant strings may be indented across newlines, if they are
            # docstrings; fold spaces after newlines when comparing. Similarly,
            # trailing and leading space may be removed.
            if (
                isinstance(node, ast.Constant)
                and field == "value"
                and isinstance(value, (str, bytes))
            ):
                lineend = "\n" if isinstance(value, str) else b"\n"
                normalized = lineend.join([line.strip() for line in value.splitlines()])
            else:
```

Running timeit suggests that it is about 2.5x quicker too - though this is likely irrelevant since this isn't going to be run too many times...
Hm, why does Black turn it from bytes to str? That seems itself like a bug.

> Hm, why does Black turn it from bytes to str? That seems itself like a bug.

Actually, from my reading of the code, I think that it is the other way around. The file being formatted is decoded when it is loaded so I would have expected the docstring to be a str... and this is the case when formatting Python 3 but not when formatting Python 2, it seems. In the latter case, blib2to3 is used to do the parsing so I don't know whether it is a bug in that library or in the way that black is using it...

issue.title: Inconsistent formatting of decorators
issue.body:
Formatting of decorators does not appear to be consistent. Consider the following code snippet:
```python
@atexit.register
def _writeback_cache():
    ...
```
Sometimes this is left unchanged and sometimes is reformatted with a space between the `@` and the `atexit.register`. The reformatting seems to be stable for a single user and a single commit but differs between different users and different commit.

I have not been able to reproduce this reliably but, as an example, I did a big commit that blackened all files under a given directory and, if I run `black` on the same directory today, it would reformat 12 of the ~220 files due to this issue - including some that are unchanged since the commit that was supposed to blacken them...

- Version: black, version 20.8b1
- OS and Python version: Windows/Python 3.6.3

_Does this bug also happen on master?_

> I've installed master in a venv and run it on the same directory as mentioned above. It would reformat 8 files, some of which were in the 12 that 20.8b1 would have formatted but some were not.

OK, I take that back. When I actually ran master on the codebase, the changes were due to hex literals now being converted to lower case, rather than upper case. The one decorator that had been changed to have a space due to this bug, was reformatted without a space.

Any idea when there is a new release planned on PyPI?

issue.title: INTERNAL ERROR: Black produced code that is not equivalent to the source.
issue.body:
[blk_kevvs06_.log](https://github.com/psf/black/files/5803772/blk_kevvs06_.log)
**Describe the bug** A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
Black produced code that is not equivalent to the source and reported this on the command line as an internal error.
See attached output file.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**

- Version: black, version 20.8b1
- OS and Python version: Fedora Rawhide / Python 3.9.1
[blk_kevvs06_.log](https://github.com/psf/black/files/5803785/blk_kevvs06_.log)

issue.title: INTERNAL ERROR: Black produced code that is not equivalent to the source.
issue.body:
**Describe the bug** When running black over the following code:
```
from pestincl import SCRIPT_FAILURE

class Suite:
    def fail(self, msg=None):
        """
        Fail immediately, with the given message.
        """
        raise SCRIPT_FAILURE, msg

    def add_failure(self):
        """ A call has failed. Record this. """
        self.num_failures += 1

    def hangup_all(self, who = None, num_at_once = 10, sleep_hangups = 1.0):
        """ Hang up all phones that are off hook.
        """
        pass
```
The error `INTERNAL ERROR: Black produced code that is not equivalent to the source.` is reported

**To Reproduce** Run black over code snippet posted above

**Expected behavior** Black formats the file without error

**Environment :**

- Version: 20.8b1
- OS and Python version: Centos 7 / Python 2.7.5 (although code was from a python 2 script, I don't think it's a python 2 specific issue)

**Does this bug also happen on master?** Yes, it repos on https://black.now.sh/?version=master


**Additional context** Output of the of the diff file:
```
--- src
+++ dst
@@ -197,11 +197,11 @@
           body=
             Expr(
               value=
                 Constant(
                   value=
-                    b' Hang up all phones that are off hook.\n        ',  # bytes
+                    b'Hang up all phones that are off hook.',  # bytes
                 )  # /Constant
             )  # /Expr
             Pass(
             )  # /Pass
           decorator_list=
```

issue.title: PythonTidy.py: INTERNAL ERROR: Black produced code that is not equivalent to the source.
issue.body: I ran black on https://github.com/witsch/PythonTidy/blob/master/PythonTidy.py and got INTERNAL ERROR: Black produced code that is not equivalent to the source. black, version 20.8b1

body: I used `2to3` to update a file from Python2 to Python3, but it had mixed white space afterwards, which black choked on. I ran the file through the Python interpreter which allowed me to discover the issue. Once I fixed the white space, then I re-ran black and it was happy.

issue.title: Handle Docstrings as bytes + strip all whitespace
issue.body:
(Eventually) reproduced with a test and 'fixed'.

Successfully ran:
* `tox -e py`
* `tox -e fuzz`
* `black-primer`

(fixes #1844, fixes #1923, fixes #1851, fixes #2002, fixes #2103)
